inlineContent.text: Reads and writes can be considered to be non-blocking.  Reading
settings with
is typically extremely fast: on
approximately the same order of magnitude (but slower than) a
[struct[HashTable](//documentation/glib/hashtable] lookup.  Writing settings is also extremely fast in
terms of time to return to your application, but can be extremely expensive
for other threads and other processes.  Many settings backends
(including dconf) have lazy initialisation which means in the common
case of the user using their computer without modifying any settings
a lot of work can be avoided.  For dconf, the D-Bus service doesn’t
even need to be started in this case.  For this reason, you should
only ever modify
keys in response to explicit user action.
Particular care should be paid to ensure that modifications are not
made during startup — for example, when setting the initial value
of preferences widgets.  The built-in [method
functionality is careful not to write settings in response to notify signals
as a result of modifications that it makes to widgets.
When creating a
instance, you have to specify a schema
that describes the keys in your settings and their types and default
values, as well as some other information.
Normally, a schema has a fixed path that determines where the settings
are stored in the conceptual global tree of settings. However, schemas
can also be ‘
’, i.e. not equipped with
a fixed path. This is
useful e.g. when the schema describes an ‘account’, and you want to be
able to store a arbitrary number of accounts.
Paths must start with and end with a forward slash character (
and must not contain two sequential slash characters.  Paths should
be chosen based on a domain name associated with the program or
library to which the settings belong.  Examples of paths are
and
Paths should not start with
or
as
they often did in GConf.
Unlike other configuration systems (like GConf), GSettings does not
restrict keys to basic types like strings and numbers. GSettings stores
values as [struct[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant], and allows any [type[VariantType](//documentation/glib/varianttype] for
keys. Key names are restricted to lowercase characters, numbers and
Furthermore, the names must begin with a lowercase character, must not end
with a
, and must not contain consecutive dashes.
Similar to GConf, the default values in GSettings schemas can be
localized, but the localized values are stored in gettext catalogs
and looked up with the domain that is specified in the
attribute of the
or
elements and the category that is specified in the
attribute of
the
element. The string which is translated includes all text in
the
element, including any surrounding quotation marks.
The
attribute must be set to
or
, and sets the
The
category should be used by default; use
for
translatable date or time formats. A translation comment can be added as an
XML comment immediately above the
element — it is recommended to
add these comments to aid translators understand the meaning and
implications of the default value. An optional translation
attribute can be set on the
element to disambiguate multiple
defaults which use the same string.
For example:

inlineContent.text: Translations of default values must remain syntactically valid serialized
[struct[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant]s (e.g. retaining any surrounding quotation marks) or
runtime errors will occur.
GSettings uses schemas in a compact binary form that is created
by the
utility. The input is a schema description in an XML format.
A DTD for the gschema XML format can be found here:
The
tool expects schema
files to have the extension
At runtime, schemas are identified by their ID (as specified in the
attribute of the
element). The convention for schema
IDs is to use a dotted name, similar in style to a D-Bus bus name,
e.g.
. In particular, if the settings are
for a specific service that owns a D-Bus bus name, the D-Bus bus name
and schema ID should match. For schemas which deal with settings not
associated with one named application, the ID should not use
StudlyCaps, e.g.
In addition to [struct[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant] types, keys can have types that have
enumerated types. These can be described by a
or
element, as seen in the
second example below. The underlying type of such a key
is string, but you can use [method
[method
], [method
[method
] access the numeric values corresponding to
the string value of enum and flags keys.

inlineContent.text: An example for ranges, choices and enumerated types:
Default values are defined in the schemas that get installed by
an application. Sometimes, it is necessary for a vendor or distributor
to adjust these defaults. Since patching the XML source for the schema
is inconvenient and error-prone,
reads so-called ‘vendor
override’ files. These are keyfiles in the same directory as the XML
schema sources which can override default values. The schema ID serves
as the group name in the key file, and the values are expected in
serialized [struct[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant] form, as in the following example:
expects schema files to have the extension
A very convenient feature of GSettings lets you bind [class[Object](//documentation/gobject/object]
properties directly to settings, using [method
]. Once a
[class[Object](//documentation/gobject/object] property has been bound to a setting, changes on
either side are automatically propagated to the other side. GSettings handles
details like mapping between [class[Object](//documentation/gobject/object] and [struct[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant]
types, and preventing infinite cycles.
This makes it very easy to hook up a preferences dialog to the
underlying settings. To make this even more convenient, GSettings
looks for a boolean property with the name
and
automatically binds it to the writability of the bound setting.
If this ‘magic’ gets in the way, it can be suppressed with the
flag.
A relocatable schema is one with no
attribute specified on its
element. By using [ctor
object can be instantiated for a relocatable schema, assigning a path to the
instance. Paths passed to [ctor
] will typically be
constructed dynamically from a constant prefix plus some form of instance
identifier; but they must still be valid GSettings paths. Paths could also
be constant and used with a globally installed schema originating from a
dependency library.
For example, a relocatable schema could be used to store geometry information
for different windows in an application. If the schema ID was
, it could be instantiated for paths
, etc. If any of the paths are well-known
they can be specified as
elements in the parent schema, e.g.:

template.
If an enumerated type defined in a C header file is to be used in a GSettings
schema, it can either be defined manually using an
element in the
schema XML, or it can be extracted automatically from the C header. This
approach is preferred, as it ensures the two representations are always
synchronised. To do so, add the following to the relevant

It exposes methods that can operate on this data type through

instance.
